which is relatively large and a negatively charged electron, that goes round it. Electric match? I think an electric match will go well on
that. Yep. Oh, look at the tension on the balloon! Hold it, I’ve really gone for it and blown
that one up. The tension! What happens is that hydrogen is reacting
with oxygen and H2 plus O2 reacts to form H2O and an oxygen atom and then that oxygen
atom goes on to react with another hydrogen molecule to make more water and the reaction
generates a lot of heat and that heat, heats up more gas to make it react faster, so you
generate more and more heat, so the reaction that begins quite slowly with the first few
molecules, runs away and that is why you get the explosion. So here we have a rather large balloon of
hydrogen, Neil is just preparing our electric match which we are going to attach to the
side of this balloon. And some of the biggest explosions in the
20th century, the Chernobyl reactor, the space shuttle that blew up when it was taking off,
were in fact explosions caused by hydrogen and oxygen. So we’ve filled up a balloon of hydrogen,
and I think if you look at the hydrogen balloon you will see that it is slightly larger than
those we have attempted before. Now we are going to try to detonate it or burn the hydrogen,
in the air by giving it a match and the match we are going to use is again an electric match,
which is connected to our detonator box. If you stick a pin in the balloon, the balloon
will burst because the rubber will break, but the hydrogen will come out and it won’t
react with the oxygen because the hydrogen is cool, it’s at the same temperature as
the air, but the reaction of hydrogen and oxygen like many reactions involves so called
activation energy, you have to put in a certain amount of energy to get it going. But once
you get it going, you get more heat coming out, than you put in to start it off. So, let’s arm the circuit, 5-4-3-2-1. That was more like it. Lovely! When Pete puts the match to the balloon, first
of all the match burns a hole in the balloon, and then the heat gets the hydrogen and oxygen
near the outside of the balloon and they start reacting and the heat then spreads through
the volume of the hydrogen and oxygen, faster probably than the balloon is bursting and
as it spreads through the temperature builds up and up and up because you are generating
so much heat. The reason that you hear a noise, is because,
it causes a rise in pressure which sends a pressure wave out through the air and it hits
your ears or the microphone on your camera. I honestly don’t know why you see any colour.
I suspect that the colour may actually be caused by the burning balloon which contains
carbon and is really like the flame on a candle. Because normally when you have a hydrogen/oxygen
flame you don’t see any colour at all. Alternatively, it may be some impurities in the gas, but
I suspect that what you are seeing in the fire ball is just the burning of the balloon.
The other thing which is really quite exciting about hydrogen is that in principle if you
heat hydrogen to really high temperatures, you can get two hydrogen atoms to fuse together,
or rather, it will not work with hydrogen, but it will work with a heavier form of hydrogen
which is know as deuterium where instead of a proton and an electron, you have a proton
and a neutron, which is a neutral particle, and an electron, and two molecules of deuterium
can fuse together to make one atom of helium which has two protons, two neutrons, and two
electrons and this produces a lot of energy. It is the basis of the so-called hydrogen
bombs, which are like super atomic bombs, but which require an enormously high temperature
to get the reaction to go. You can probably hear it hitting and fizzing
into the bottle there. There is great hope that in the end much of
the world’s energy crisis can be solved by doing this so called nuclear fusion of
deuterium to make helium which would produce energy extremely cleanly. So here, we’ll just tie it off, if my Welsh
hands can actually tie a knot on a balloon, ‘cause, you know we are all a little bit
bizarre. Deuterium gas, in all its properties, will
be very similar to that of hydrogen, of course it is denser, because it has a neutron as
well as a proton but it is still much lighter than air so a deuterium balloon will still
float up to the ceiling and make Pete look just as stupid as the hydrogen one. You’ve got to keep hold of it. Or you lose it Or you lose it, you know! I was thinking more of fusing it, that sounds
like a really big explosion we could do out the back. No! Fusing reactors are way beyond what Pete
can do unless he is a lot cleverer than I think. I got a balloon! I had a balloon of hydrogen! That is the second time you have done that! Now it’s going to go up there eventually
anyway!

Question: According to the professor, which clean source of energy could potentially solve the energy challenge?
Options: A. Nuclear fusion., B. Nuclear fission., C. Hydrogen combustion.
Correct Option: A

Question 1: What is the simplest atom, consisting of a positively charged proton and a negatively charged electron? Options: A. Helium, B. Oxygen, C. Hydrogen, D. Deuterium Correct Option: C
Question 2: What happens when hydrogen reacts with oxygen in the presence of heat? Options: A. The reaction slows down and produces less heat, B. The reaction generates more heat and speeds up, C. The reaction remains unchanged, D. The reaction produces water but no heat Correct Option: B
Question 3: A large balloon filled with hydrogen gas is ignited with an electric match. What is likely to happen? Options: A. The balloon will slowly deflate and produce a small amount of heat, B. The balloon will burst and produce a loud noise due to a rapid release of pressure, C. The balloon will float away without any reaction, D. The balloon will remain unchanged Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the term for the energy required to initiate a chemical reaction, such as the combustion of hydrogen and oxygen? Options: A. Activation energy, B. Reaction energy, C. Combustion energy, D. Thermal energy Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the likely cause of the color observed during the combustion of a hydrogen-filled balloon? Options: A. The burning of the balloon material, B. The reaction between hydrogen and oxygen, C. The presence of impurities in the gas, D. The high temperature of the reaction Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the name of the heavier form of hydrogen that can undergo nuclear fusion to produce helium? Options: A. Deuterium, B. Tritium, C. Helium-3, D. Hydrogen-2 Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the potential benefit of nuclear fusion reactions, such as the fusion of deuterium to produce helium? Options: A. Production of a large amount of greenhouse gases, B. Release of a large amount of radioactive waste, C. Production of energy extremely cleanly, D. Generation of a small amount of energy Correct Option: C
Question 8: A deuterium-filled balloon is compared to a hydrogen-filled balloon. What is the expected difference in their behavior? Options: A. The deuterium balloon will sink to the ground, while the hydrogen balloon will float away, B. The deuterium balloon will float up to the ceiling, just like the hydrogen balloon, C. The deuterium balloon will react more slowly with oxygen than the hydrogen balloon, D. The deuterium balloon will produce a different color during combustion Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the primary reason for the loud noise produced during the combustion of a hydrogen-filled balloon? Options: A. The rapid release of pressure due to the reaction, B. The burning of the balloon material, C. The presence of impurities in the gas, D. The high temperature of the reaction Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the name of the type of bomb that relies on the nuclear fusion of deuterium to produce a large amount of energy? Options: A. Atomic bomb, B. Hydrogen bomb, C. Nuclear bomb, D. Fusion bomb Correct Option: B

Question 7: What is the potential benefit of nuclear fusion reactions, such as the fusion of deuterium to produce helium?

atom goes on to react with another hydrogen molecule to make more water and the reaction
generates a lot of heat and that heat, heats up more gas to make it react faster, so you
generate more and more heat, so the reaction that begins quite slowly with the first few
molecules, runs away and that is why you get the explosion. So here we have a rather large balloon of
hydrogen, Neil is just preparing our electric match which we are going to attach to the
side of this balloon. And some of the biggest explosions in the
20th century, the Chernobyl reactor, the space shuttle that blew up when it was taking off,
were in fact explosions caused by hydrogen and oxygen. So we’ve filled up a balloon of hydrogen,
and I think if you look at the hydrogen balloon you will see that it is slightly larger than
those we have attempted before. Now we are going to try to detonate it or burn the hydrogen,
in the air by giving it a match and the match we are going to use is again an electric match,
which is connected to our detonator box. If you stick a pin in the balloon, the balloon
will burst because the rubber will break, but the hydrogen will come out and it won’t
react with the oxygen because the hydrogen is cool, it’s at the same temperature as
the air, but the reaction of hydrogen and oxygen like many reactions involves so called
activation energy, you have to put in a certain amount of energy to get it going. But once
you get it going, you get more heat coming out, than you put in to start it off. So, let’s arm the circuit, 5-4-3-2-1. That was more like it. Lovely! When Pete puts the match to the balloon, first
of all the match burns a hole in the balloon, and then the heat gets the hydrogen and oxygen
near the outside of the balloon and they start reacting and the heat then spreads through
the volume of the hydrogen and oxygen, faster probably than the balloon is bursting and
as it spreads through the temperature builds up and up and up because you are generating
so much heat. The reason that you hear a noise, is because,
it causes a rise in pressure which sends a pressure wave out through the air and it hits
your ears or the microphone on your camera. I honestly don’t know why you see any colour.
I suspect that the colour may actually be caused by the burning balloon which contains
carbon and is really like the flame on a candle. Because normally when you have a hydrogen/oxygen
flame you don’t see any colour at all. Alternatively, it may be some impurities in the gas, but
I suspect that what you are seeing in the fire ball is just the burning of the balloon.
The other thing which is really quite exciting about hydrogen is that in principle if you
heat hydrogen to really high temperatures, you can get two hydrogen atoms to fuse together,
or rather, it will not work with hydrogen, but it will work with a heavier form of hydrogen
which is know as deuterium where instead of a proton and an electron, you have a proton
and a neutron, which is a neutral particle, and an electron, and two molecules of deuterium
can fuse together to make one atom of helium which has two protons, two neutrons, and two
electrons and this produces a lot of energy. It is the basis of the so-called hydrogen
bombs, which are like super atomic bombs, but which require an enormously high temperature
to get the reaction to go. You can probably hear it hitting and fizzing
into the bottle there. There is great hope that in the end much of
the world’s energy crisis can be solved by doing this so called nuclear fusion of
deuterium to make helium which would produce energy extremely cleanly. So here, we’ll just tie it off, if my Welsh
hands can actually tie a knot on a balloon, ‘cause, you know we are all a little bit
bizarre. Deuterium gas, in all its properties, will
be very similar to that of hydrogen, of course it is denser, because it has a neutron as
well as a proton but it is still much lighter than air so a deuterium balloon will still
float up to the ceiling and make Pete look just as stupid as the hydrogen one. You’ve got to keep hold of it. Or you lose it Or you lose it, you know! I was thinking more of fusing it, that sounds
like a really big explosion we could do out the back. No! Fusing reactors are way beyond what Pete
can do unless he is a lot cleverer than I think. I got a balloon! I had a balloon of hydrogen! That is the second time you have done that! Now it’s going to go up there eventually
anyway!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: You are holding three balloons, each containing a different gas. Balloon A is full of hydrogen, balloon B is full of deuterium, and balloon C is full of carbon dioxide. When released, one balloon falls to the floor and the other two rise to the ceiling, with one balloon rising faster than the other. Which of the following statements is true?
Options: A. Balloon A is on the floor and B rose faster than C., B. Balloon C is on the floor and A rose faster than B., C. Balloon C is on the floor and B rose faster than A.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the simplest atom, consisting of a positively charged proton and a negatively charged electron? Options: A. Helium, B. Oxygen, C. Hydrogen, D. Deuterium Correct Option: C
Question 2: What happens when hydrogen reacts with oxygen in the presence of heat? Options: A. The reaction slows down and produces less heat, B. The reaction generates more heat and speeds up, C. The reaction remains unchanged, D. The reaction produces water but no heat Correct Option: B
Question 3: A large balloon filled with hydrogen gas is ignited with an electric match. What is likely to happen? Options: A. The balloon will slowly deflate and produce a small amount of heat, B. The balloon will burst and produce a loud noise due to a rapid release of pressure, C. The balloon will float away without any reaction, D. The balloon will remain unchanged Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the term for the energy required to initiate a chemical reaction, such as the combustion of hydrogen and oxygen? Options: A. Activation energy, B. Reaction energy, C. Combustion energy, D. Thermal energy Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the likely cause of the color observed during the combustion of a hydrogen-filled balloon? Options: A. The burning of the balloon material, B. The reaction between hydrogen and oxygen, C. The presence of impurities in the gas, D. The high temperature of the reaction Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the name of the heavier form of hydrogen that can undergo nuclear fusion to produce helium? Options: A. Deuterium, B. Tritium, C. Helium-3, D. Hydrogen-2 Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the potential benefit of nuclear fusion reactions, such as the fusion of deuterium to produce helium? Options: A. Production of a large amount of greenhouse gases, B. Release of a large amount of radioactive waste, C. Production of energy extremely cleanly, D. Generation of a small amount of energy Correct Option: C
Question 8: A deuterium-filled balloon is compared to a hydrogen-filled balloon. What is the expected difference in their behavior? Options: A. The deuterium balloon will sink to the ground, while the hydrogen balloon will float away, B. The deuterium balloon will float up to the ceiling, just like the hydrogen balloon, C. The deuterium balloon will react more slowly with oxygen than the hydrogen balloon, D. The deuterium balloon will produce a different color during combustion Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the primary reason for the loud noise produced during the combustion of a hydrogen-filled balloon? Options: A. The rapid release of pressure due to the reaction, B. The burning of the balloon material, C. The presence of impurities in the gas, D. The high temperature of the reaction Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the name of the type of bomb that relies on the nuclear fusion of deuterium to produce a large amount of energy? Options: A. Atomic bomb, B. Hydrogen bomb, C. Nuclear bomb, D. Fusion bomb Correct Option: B

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is Question 8.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the behavior of three balloons filled with different gases (hydrogen, deuterium, and carbon dioxide) when released. The correct answer states that the balloon filled with carbon dioxide will fall to the floor, and the balloons filled with hydrogen and deuterium will rise to the ceiling, with the hydrogen balloon rising faster than the deuterium balloon.

Question 8 asks about the expected difference in behavior between a deuterium-filled balloon and a hydrogen-filled balloon. The correct answer states that the deuterium balloon will float up to the ceiling, just like the hydrogen balloon. Although this question does not directly compare the behavior of three balloons, it addresses the relative behavior of deuterium and hydrogen balloons, which is a key aspect of the ground truth MCQ.

While the other generated MCQs may touch on related topics, such as the properties of hydrogen and deuterium or the behavior of balloons filled with these gases, Question 8 is the most similar to the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content.

It should be alright! There it goes! Aww,
actually that’s quite spectacular at the end. And in my second-year, I think I love boron
far too much I think, ‘cause I talk about it too much. You love boron? I love boron! No, I used to do lots of chemistry
with boron, I kind of moved away a little bit from boron
now but I really like it. Boron is an interesting element. It is one
of the few that I have actually made myself when I was at school. Boron sits on top of the group 13. Its atomic
number is 5, so it is a metalloid, so elemental boron is a
metalloid which basically means that it has some of the properties
of a non metal and some of the properties of a metal. I mixed an oxide of boron with magnesium,
heated it up and then, it is a really dramatic reaction when
you add water at the end to try and destroy the magnesium boride
that has formed because you get puffs of gas coming
off which burst into flames rather like little anti-aircraft
guns. But boron itself was rather disappointing; it’s a sort of
brown powder. I mean there is a more of a powdery brown
boron, there are several crystalline sort of types of alatropes
of boron. There is one actually that is really, really hard,
so the black crystalline boron is actually very, very hard. It’s
just below diamond on Mohs scale of hardness, so I believe. And
actually in America, there is a town called Boron. It’s in California,
it’s got a population of around 2000 which actually was
set up around the world’s biggest borax mine which is
in California. Well it used to be transported on trains of
mules and the company that produced it used to have as their
trademark a train of 20 mules sort of going along. Of great interest to us chemists, well over
the last sort of 50, maybe sort of 60-70 years, have been the boron
hydrides or borades. So boron hydrides are basically clusters
of borons with hydrogens around them. And one of particular
use and interest in the 50s was one called pentaborane,
which basically: penta, five, it’s got five borons
in it. And Pentaborate was investigated during the cold
war or in the early part of the cold war as being a rocket
fuel. It actually burns with a green flame. They actually called
it the ‘green dragon’ because it burns with a very, very
hot green flame and also because it is pretty toxic, which
I can actually show you if I … It is probably not going to be
spectacular. And boron complexes or borax compounds are
used in a variety of things. It is not a particularly
expensive material. It is used in washing powder, particularly perborate
which when you heat it up in the washing machine when
the water gets to 60 degrees centigrade it turns into hydrogen
peroxide which can then bleach the clothes and this is why
the famous washing powder is called Persil, because the
‘per’ stands for perborate and the ‘sil’ stands for silicate
so it is really a mixture of perborate and silicate. Ok so this isn’t pentaborane because pentaborane
spontaneously combusts in the air. This is just benzene
boronic acid. It’s an organic compound with some boron in it.
So hopefully we can see, we should be able to see, if I can
get some at the end of my spatula, that it should be able to
burn with some sort of green flame. Hey, there it is. You can
also see a bit of yellow which is the organic bit going as well.
It should be alright! There it goes! Aww, actually that was
quite spectacular at the end. Ok.

through the beryllium and the beryllium does not absorb it at all which most other metals
especially those with higher molecular weights do. Beryllium-laden dust has been shown to cause

to the air we need to be able to remove the air and encase it so we use beryllium to make
a magic box around our sample, that the x-rays can come into, interact with our sample, and
then exit without interacting with the material around them. So you can see on the front of
this instrument, there is a dome shaped device, that dome, is a special vessel which is made
so that we could control the atmosphere inside and it is fabricated from beryllium metal. I talk about in my lectures, I explain that
beryllium chloride the molecule that has three atoms, two chlorine atoms and one beryllium
atom, has the three atoms arranged in the row, so it is a straight molecule so called
linear molecule. I have never seen beryllium chloride. Chemists use it on x-ray defractometers because
actually it is so lightweight it is actually got atomic number 4. The beryllium allows the x-rays to come in
and out without interacting at all. It is a fantastic device it is really useful for
really sensitive chemistry, it is a really beautiful application. The cost of that beryllium
though, that is significant, that small beryllium sample cost 15,000 Euros. It only has four protons and a number of neutrons
so if x-rays fall on atoms of beryllium they are not scattered very much so it’s like

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 9: Why is it necessary to handle beryllium with care? 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, which asks about the main problem encountered when working with beryllium dust. Both questions are concerned with the hazards of beryllium. The correct option for Question 9, "It is a toxic metal that can cause serious health problems," is similar to the correct option for the ground truth MCQ, "Beryllium is a toxic metal."

However, an even more similar question is Question 10: What is the consequence of inhaling even a small amount of beryllium dust? 

This question is more specific to the dust aspect mentioned in the ground truth MCQ and highlights the risk of beryllium dust, which aligns with the ground truth MCQ's focus on the problem encountered when working with beryllium dust.

But the most similar question is actually Question 3: What is the industrial lung disease caused by inhaling beryllium-laden dust? 

It does not match exactly the wording of the ground truth MCQ but it is focused on the health issue (a lung disease) caused by beryllium dust which is the core intent of the ground truth MCQ.

Considering all these options, the most similar generated MCQ is Question 9, but a very close match is also Question 10 and even more so Question 3.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
So you can see on the front of this instrument
is a dome shaped device. That dome is a special vessel which is made so we can control the
atmosphere inside and it is fabricated from beryllium metal. This is the beryllium which I don’t really
want to get out. Why not? Well, because it is a toxic chemical, a toxic
metal. Beryllium is an interesting element because
most chemists don’t really know about it very much at all. So beryllium is a fantastic metal, it is really,
really interesting, it’s got really lots of strange metallic properties, but one of
the most important to me is that it is transparent to x-rays. So I can shine x-rays straight
through the beryllium and the beryllium does not absorb it at all which most other metals
especially those with higher molecular weights do. Beryllium-laden dust has been shown to cause
berylliosis which is actually an industrial lung disease which causes the formation of
swollen nodules in the lungs called granulomas which is a bit gross, so I don’t really
want to open up the jar. It’s near the beginning of the periodic
table, but we rarely come across it. So at the moment we are at Matt’s lab and
we are doing some x-ray experiments on a really, really quite sensitive compound. So X-rays
themselves are absorbed by everything, ok, so when we shoot it through the air it is
absorbed by the air, so to measure the x-ray absorption of our compound which is sensitive
to the air we need to be able to remove the air and encase it so we use beryllium to make
a magic box around our sample, that the x-rays can come into, interact with our sample, and
then exit without interacting with the material around them. So you can see on the front of
this instrument, there is a dome shaped device, that dome, is a special vessel which is made
so that we could control the atmosphere inside and it is fabricated from beryllium metal. I talk about in my lectures, I explain that
beryllium chloride the molecule that has three atoms, two chlorine atoms and one beryllium
atom, has the three atoms arranged in the row, so it is a straight molecule so called
linear molecule. I have never seen beryllium chloride. Chemists use it on x-ray defractometers because
actually it is so lightweight it is actually got atomic number 4. The beryllium allows the x-rays to come in
and out without interacting at all. It is a fantastic device it is really useful for
really sensitive chemistry, it is a really beautiful application. The cost of that beryllium
though, that is significant, that small beryllium sample cost 15,000 Euros. It only has four protons and a number of neutrons
so if x-rays fall on atoms of beryllium they are not scattered very much so it’s like
the difference between shining light through a glass window and if you made it out of a
heavy material it would be like, shining through paper, it would be scattered you wouldn’t
get a good image. I’m hoping to actually do some chemistry
with beryllium which is why I’ve bought it. It is pretty toxic so we are going to
have to be very, very careful. You can’t actually breathe in the dust at all, cause
even actually one exposure has shown with some people one exposure is enough to cause
this sort of sensitive reaction. But beryllium is very poisonous so if you
do use these beryllium windows, you have to be careful not to lick your fingers. Well
good chemists shouldn’t lick their fingers anyway.

Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3
Correct Option: B

It can cause a skin irritation, D. It can cause a one-time exposure to be enough to cause a sensitive reaction Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
So comrades, welcome to the lecture. What
I am going to do now, we’re going to begin with an experiment
to illustrate this point that the oxygen molecule, O2, has
unpaired electrons. Now we’re outside just to show you the reactivity
of this lovely stuff here, liquid oxygen. So you can
see wonderful liquid oxygen is a nice blue colour. So over
here on the table we’ve got a tin tray which we’re going
to use to contain the experiment that I’m going to show you next.
So we’ve got our favourite liquid oxygen. Strongly oxidising;
very, very reactive, and here I’ve got some cotton
wool. So this is the same stuff we use to take make-up off, perhaps
our partners or our girlfriends or our wives, and this
is the same stuff we use to wipe our babies’ bums. Oxygen is an interesting element because it
exists in two forms: the taught form which we breathe all
the time is O2, two oxygen atoms joined together; and there’s
another form called ozone, and which has three atoms arranged
like the letter V, or letter V this way up. Oxygen has unpaired electrons within the molecular
orbitals, in the atomic orbitals around the structure,
and these unpaired electrons give rise to colour and
that colour is blue. So blue is often perceived to be the colour
of solvated or unpaired electrons, and you can see here the
lovely blue colour. Now lots of chemists are really scared
when they see the blue of liquid oxygen, because liquid
oxygen is very, very reactive. Generally you only make liquid oxygen
by mistake. Not like today when we’re making some on
purpose. And if you’ve made it by mistake in an uncontrolled
way, where there might be organic molecules perhaps simple
organic chemicals like hydrocarbons, grease or perhaps
a highly elaborate compound then, they tend to detonate
and they tend to cause very energetic experiments. Yeah it’s very fluffy it’s not very reactive.
It doesn’t really burn, it cinders, might smoulder. But here
we go, we’re going to pop it in the tray. So we begin with Neil’s very high-tech piece
of equipment, which is a test-tube on a piece of string.
What we’re going to do is to put some liquid nitrogen in here.
You can see liquid nitrogen – well you may not see – is colourless.
Ok? So this is liquid nitrogen, and what I hope you can see
is that this magnet, which is a pretty good magnet. Let
me just show you here with my keys, that they stick pretty
strongly to the magnet. The magnet has absolutely no affect
at all on the liquid nitrogen. I can pull the magnet and
nothing happens. And then we’re going to fill up all of the
void space, so all of the space in the cotton particles with oxygen.
So you might want to stand back after this bit Brady. So
here we go, here’s our liquid oxygen. Do you want to come in
and zoom in on me? It’s ok, I’ve got it zoomed nicely. Ok, so here you can see the lovely blue liquid
oxygen colour, going into the cotton wool particles. Let’s try the same thing with liquid oxygen.
Careful of my shoes… So here we have a match on a stick, and I
think you can see its probably alight, so we have our fire,
we have our oxygen, and we have our fuel. Now let’s see what
happens when we put them all together. The liquid oxygen is a very nice blue colour
today. So now let’s try, here’s the magnet again, and
if I take the liquid oxygen you can see I can pull it right up
here. It’s not as magnetic as my keys, but you can see there’s
a really big difference. It sticks to the magnet. So you
can see it really is magnetic. You ready? Ok. Woohoo and there she blows! And ozone is much more reactive than oxygen.
So near the earth’s surface, where you and I are at
the moment, ozone is really quite dangerous because if you breathe
it in it can start reacting with any sort of molecule that has
bonds between carbon. But in the upper atmosphere, ozone
is extremely important because it absorbs ultra-violet
light that comes from the sun and stops this ultra-violet light
attacking the molecules in biological species on the surface.
If it wasn’t for the ozone in the upper atmosphere all of us
would be, if not dead, certainly very much less comfortable
than we are at the moment. So Neil’s now connecting up a piece of tube
to oxygen cylinder and he is going to fill up this gas
jar with oxygen and we are going to do a really classic experiment:
the one that everyone learns at school and tests for oxygen,
which is to relight a glowing splint. So we have a traditional
gas jar full of oxygen. So here you can see we are burning
a splint. Ok, so this is the wood burning in excess oxygen
around us, ok. So what we are going to do is we are going to
take the splint out so it is just glowing. And if I blow on this
splint you can see it gets brighter. Now we are going to try and
relight that splint by putting it into a very oxygen-rich atmosphere.
So we’ll move over to the jar and we’ll put in our
glowing splint and you can see the flame comes back to life.
So that’s a test that everyone learns for an oxygen-rich environment. What happened? What made that happen? Well the increased oxygen content/concentration
reignites and reinitiates that oxidation of the wood or
the burning of the wood. So we’ll do that again. So there we
go: flame again.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: "Last night I had a horrible nightmare”, said the organic chemist to the theoretical one. “I could see the blue color of liquid oxygen!” Why is this beautiful liquid so feared by organic chemists?
Options: A. Because liquid oxygen is extremely toxic, B. Because liquid oxygen is extremely radioactive, C. Because liquid oxygen is extremely reactive and can cause an explosion when it comes in contact with organic compounds
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the typical color of liquid oxygen? Options: A. Red, B. Blue, C. Green, D. Colorless Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the primary reason chemists are cautious when handling liquid oxygen? Options: A. It is extremely cold., B. It is highly reactive and can cause energetic reactions., C. It is a strong oxidizing agent., D. It is toxic to humans. Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the main difference between oxygen (O2) and ozone (O3)? Options: A. The number of atoms in the molecule., B. The color of the molecule., C. The reactivity of the molecule., D. The boiling point of the molecule. Correct Option: A
Question 4: A student accidentally creates liquid oxygen in an uncontrolled environment. What is likely to happen? Options: A. The liquid oxygen will slowly evaporate., B. The liquid oxygen will react with nearby organic molecules, potentially causing an explosion., C. The liquid oxygen will freeze the surrounding materials., D. The liquid oxygen will have no effect on the environment. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the purpose of the experiment involving the glowing splint and oxygen-rich environment? Options: A. To demonstrate the reactivity of liquid oxygen., B. To test for the presence of oxygen in a gas jar., C. To show the effect of oxygen on combustion reactions., D. To measure the boiling point of liquid oxygen. Correct Option: B
Question 6: Why is ozone (O3) important in the upper atmosphere? Options: A. It absorbs ultra-violet light, protecting biological species on the surface., B. It reacts with carbon-based molecules, creating new compounds., C. It is a strong oxidizing agent, helping to clean the atmosphere., D. It is a greenhouse gas, contributing to climate change. Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the result of placing a magnet near liquid nitrogen? Options: A. The liquid nitrogen is attracted to the magnet., B. The liquid nitrogen is repelled by the magnet., C. The magnet has no effect on the liquid nitrogen., D. The liquid nitrogen changes color. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the likely outcome of breathing in ozone (O3) near the Earth's surface? Options: A. It will have no effect on human health., B. It will cause a mild allergic reaction., C. It will start reacting with carbon-based molecules in the body, potentially causing harm., D. It will increase oxygen levels in the blood. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the difference in the reaction between liquid oxygen and a magnet compared to liquid nitrogen and a magnet? Options: A. Liquid oxygen is repelled by the magnet, while liquid nitrogen is attracted., B. Liquid oxygen is attracted to the magnet, while liquid nitrogen is not affected., C. Liquid oxygen and liquid nitrogen both react similarly to the magnet., D. The magnet has no effect on either liquid oxygen or liquid nitrogen. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the primary reason for the blue color of liquid oxygen? Options: A. The presence of impurities in the liquid oxygen., B. The molecular structure of oxygen, which includes unpaired electrons., C. The temperature of the liquid oxygen., D. The pressure of the liquid oxygen. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it deals with the reactivity of liquid oxygen and its potential to cause an explosion when it comes into contact with organic compounds. The options provided in Question 4 also align with the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ, which is that liquid oxygen is extremely reactive and can cause an explosion when it comes in contact with organic compounds.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4

the burning of the wood. So we’ll do that again. So there we
go: flame again.

Options: A. Because it absorbs dangerous infra-red light that comes from the sun, B. Because it absorbs dangerous ultra-violet light that comes from the sun, C. Because it absorbs dangerous visible light that comes from the sun
Correct Option: B

This is a balloon of Helium, and Helium is a very small gas. we use in this case to find leaks in high pressure in high vacuum operators, because it's very very small, finds the smallest, smallest holes. But just like Hydrogen, it's also very very light. And you know, in the past we used Hydrogen to fill balloons, for transport, and now you see the Goodyear Blimp, sporting occasions, filled with Helium.  So Helium is probably the most unreactive of the elements. It has a mass of 4, so it weighs four times as much as a Hydrogen atom, but Hydrogen is an H2 molecule, whereas Helium exists as isolated atoms, so that the a Helium molecule weighs twice as much as Hydrogen. See here, we have a Helium filled balloon, and it's extremely light, so I'm not gonna let it go right now so I will lose it to the ceiling. So I'm just gonna put on a piece of string. tie a lead around it again. Helium can not be synthesized in nature because it is just an element. It is found as a component of natural gas in some places, particularly in the United States, because it is formed by the radioactive decay of minerals underground, and these form Helium, which is trapped with the natural gas. So here we have a Helium balloon floating, because it's displacing its volume of air, and it'll float quite nicely. It's actually quite hard to contain, so the piece of string and the heavy stand is there holding it down, because we don't really wanna lose it. A little bit of a bang, but that's just bang of the gas escaping, it didn't burn. Yep, it's unreactive, it's an inert gas. The molecule is very light, so once it is in the atmosphere it will eventually go out into outer space. So that we are, in theory at least, likely to run out of Helium in eventual future. If it is just released to the atmosphere.  So what I got here is a balloon of Helium, and it's really really light, and it's displacing a lot of volume, so if I let go of it it's gonna fly like a balloon. So what we're gonna do is I'm gonna hold it down here, and Neil is gonna cool it for me using some liquid Nitrogen. Now you can see Neil is using gloves, because it's very very cold. Okay, so as he cools the balloon the gasses inside are slowing down, and they take up much much less volume as we slow them down, and now you can see it's displacing less volume, so the balloon is quite happy to sit on the table. If we stop pouring the liquid Nitrogen onto it now, and watch what happens as the balloon starts to warm up again. Because the gases are gaining more energy, and they are occupying more space, and becoming more bouyant, so the Helium comes back to the ceiling, where it really wants to be. Fantastic element. Very light, very fun. Because the speed of sound is much greater in Helium than it is in ordinary gases. It is also very useful as a liquid. It only liquifies at very low temperature. Its boiling point is -269 degrees centigrade. But if you cool things with liquid Helium, you get very strange properties, for example, some materials lose their electrical resistance. So liquid Helium is used for magnets when you need very powerful magnets, and for example, they're used magnets from magnetic resonance imaging in hospitals. **Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Helium is formed in stars by fusion of deuterium atoms. How is it formed on Earth?
Options: A. In the same way, by nuclear fusion., B. By extracting it from the sun., C. By radioactive decay of minerals underground, where it is found trapped with natural gas.
Correct Option: C

It would be trapped in the atmosphere forever., C. It would eventually escape into outer space., D. It would be absorbed by plants. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What happens to the volume of a gas when it is cooled? Options: A. It increases., B. It decreases., C. It remains the same., D. It becomes zero. Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why does a person's voice sound squeaky when they breathe in Helium? Options: A. Because Helium is toxic., B. Because the speed of sound is slower in Helium., C. Because the speed of sound is faster in Helium., D. Because Helium is a heavy gas. Correct Option: C

Question 8: What would happen if you were to use a vacuum pump to pump hard on liquid Helium? Options: A. The boiling point would increase., B. The boiling point would remain the same., C. The boiling point would decrease., D. The Helium would solidify. Correct Option: C

Because liquid Helium can be used to create powerful magnets., D. Because Helium is a good insulator. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is one potential consequence of releasing large amounts of Helium into the atmosphere? Options: A. The atmosphere would become more reactive., B. The atmosphere would become less reactive., C. We would eventually run out of Helium., D. The atmosphere would become more dense. Correct Option: C

And you know, in the past we used Hydrogen to fill balloons, for transport, and now you see the Goodyear Blimp, sporting occasions, filled with Helium.  So Helium is probably the most unreactive of the elements. It has a mass of 4, so it weighs four times as much as a Hydrogen atom, but Hydrogen is an H2 molecule, whereas Helium exists as isolated atoms, so that the a Helium molecule weighs twice as much as Hydrogen. See here, we have a Helium filled balloon, and it's extremely light, so I'm not gonna let it go right now so I will lose it to the ceiling. So I'm just gonna put on a piece of string. tie a lead around it again. Helium can not be synthesized in nature because it is just an element. It is found as a component of natural gas in some places, particularly in the United States, because it is formed by the radioactive decay of minerals underground, and these form Helium, which is trapped with the natural gas. So here we have a Helium balloon floating, because it's displacing its volume of air, and it'll float quite nicely. It's actually quite hard to contain, so the piece of string and the heavy stand is there holding it down, because we don't really wanna lose it. If we take a balloon of another light gas, and that's Hydrogen, and we add a match to it or we set it on fire, it will burn really really quickly, and really energetically, because it makes for lots and lots of water, Hydrogen plus Oxygen.  We're gonna do the same experiment now, but we're gonna do it with a Helium filled balloon, and see if that'll burn. So here we have a technical match on a stick, and we're gonna offer it out to our floating balloon of Helium. Let's see what happens this time.  A little bit of a bang, but that's just bang of the gas escaping, it didn't burn. Yep, it's unreactive, it's an inert gas. The molecule is very light, so once it is in the atmosphere it will eventually go out into outer space. So that we are, in theory at least, likely to run out of Helium in eventual future. If it is just released to the atmosphere.  So what I got here is a balloon of Helium, and it's really really light, and it's displacing a lot of volume, so if I let go of it it's gonna fly like a balloon. So what we're gonna do is I'm gonna hold it down here, and Neil is gonna cool it for me using some liquid Nitrogen. Now you can see Neil is using gloves, because it's very very cold. Okay, so as he cools the balloon the gasses inside are slowing down, and they take up much much less volume as we slow them down, and now you can see it's displacing less volume, so the balloon is quite happy to sit on the table. If we stop pouring the liquid Nitrogen onto it now, and watch what happens as the balloon starts to warm up again. Because the gases are gaining more energy, and they are occupying more space, and becoming more bouyant, so the Helium comes back to the ceiling, where it really wants to be.  The Helium has a whole series of useful properties because it's a very light gas, if you breathe in Helium, you then start speaking like Donald Duck, in a very squeaky voice.  Helium. Fantastic element. Very light, very fun. Because the speed of sound is much greater in Helium than it is in ordinary gases. It is also very useful as a liquid. It only liquifies at very low temperature. Its boiling point is -269 degrees centigrade. But if you cool things with liquid Helium, you get very strange properties, for example, some materials lose their electrical resistance. So liquid Helium is used for magnets when you need very powerful magnets, and for example, they're used magnets from magnetic resonance imaging in hospitals. If you use a vacuum pump to pump hard on the Helium, the boiling point will go even lower, and you can go to nearly two degrees absolute. And so Helium is very important for all sorts of refrigiration. Captions by www.SubPLY.com

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A helium atom weighs four times as much as a hydrogen atom...
Options: A. and helium molecules weigh four times as much as hydrogen molecules because both are diatomic molecules., B. but much less than a hydrogen molecule because the hydrogen molecule is diatomic., C. only twice as much as a hydrogen molecule because the hydrogen molecule is diatomic.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary reason Helium is used to find leaks in high-pressure and high-vacuum operators? Options: A. It is very reactive., B. It is very light., C. It is very small., D. It is very dense. Correct Option: C
Question 2: Why did people switch from using Hydrogen to Helium for filling balloons? Options: A. Helium is more reactive than Hydrogen., B. Helium is lighter than Hydrogen., C. Helium is safer than Hydrogen because it doesn't burn., D. Helium is cheaper than Hydrogen. Correct Option: C
Question 3: If you were to release a Helium-filled balloon into the atmosphere, what would eventually happen to the Helium? Options: A. It would react with Oxygen to form water., B. It would be trapped in the atmosphere forever., C. It would eventually escape into outer space., D. It would be absorbed by plants. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What happens to the volume of a gas when it is cooled? Options: A. It increases., B. It decreases., C. It remains the same., D. It becomes zero. Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why does a person's voice sound squeaky when they breathe in Helium? Options: A. Because Helium is toxic., B. Because the speed of sound is slower in Helium., C. Because the speed of sound is faster in Helium., D. Because Helium is a heavy gas. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is one of the useful properties of liquid Helium? Options: A. It is very dense., B. It is very viscous., C. Some materials lose their electrical resistance when cooled with it., D. It is very corrosive. Correct Option: C
Question 7: At what temperature does Helium liquify? Options: A. -100 degrees centigrade., B. -269 degrees centigrade., C. 0 degrees centigrade., D. 100 degrees centigrade. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What would happen if you were to use a vacuum pump to pump hard on liquid Helium? Options: A. The boiling point would increase., B. The boiling point would remain the same., C. The boiling point would decrease., D. The Helium would solidify. Correct Option: C
Question 9: Why is Helium used in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) machines? Options: A. Because it is a ferromagnetic material., B. Because it is a good conductor of electricity., C. Because liquid Helium can be used to create powerful magnets., D. Because Helium is a good insulator. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is one potential consequence of releasing large amounts of Helium into the atmosphere? Options: A. The atmosphere would become more reactive., B. The atmosphere would become less reactive., C. We would eventually run out of Helium., D. The atmosphere would become more dense. Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

So the last time we tried to film chlorine
experiments we found that the chlorine cylinder itself had
a slight problem, it was seized here. But the Stig
has acquired another cylinder of chlorine. So you know
what this means, it means that we feel duty-bound to
increase the intensity of our chlorine video and show you
some chemistry with chlorine. Chlorine is an element that many people have
heard of. It’s a greenish-yellow gas which consists
of, the gas consists of two chlorine atoms bonded together
so it’s Cl2 and it’s much heavier than air. Incredibly reactive, incredibly poisonous,
not a very nice compound at all. Ok so Neil is about to open
the cylinder of chlorine to allow some of the chlorine
gas to leak through the pipe into the, to the flask in
the fume hood. Chlorine sits in the right-hand side of the
periodic table in the halogens in group, well, some people
say seven, some people say seventeen. Really what that
says is that chlorine wants another electron to get
that noble gas configuration and it will move heaven
and earth to get that electron! So during the First World War it was used
as a chemical weapon. The gas could spread across the battlefields
and when it came to the trenches, which were holes in
the ground, it would fall into the trenches and fill them
up. You can see the yellow colour against the
white background on the paper, so now we’re starting
to fill that flask with chlorine; it’s quite dense,
so it will stick to the bottom of the flask it’s not like
a light gas like hydrogen or helium, it won’t come upwards.
So now you can see the colour in that chlorine is really
quite intense. It wasn’t a terribly good weapon because

out. So we’ll just put a stopper in to contain
the gas while we prepare the rest of the experiment. Chlorine is quite corrosive, it reacts with
water to make an acid, HCl, hydrochloric acid which can
attack people’s lungs. The lungs generate fluid, they fill
up with fluid and quickly the person drowns in their own fluid.

fittings on people’s battle dress, the brass buttons,
brass buckles, all went green as well. But it’s not a terribly

with moisture in the air. So now you can see the

You can make salt by burning the metal sodium in chlorine,

to make the chloride ion Cl-, and the chloride ion
is perfectly innocuous, you can drink, you can eat chloride,
whereas chlorine itself is very poisonous. Oh it’s warm, it’s not too hot to touch

reaction, very, very reactive with chlorine.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which common salt you will obtain in the reaction between metallic sodium and chlorine gas?
Options: A. Sodium chloride, B. Sodium hypochlorite, C. Sodium it doesn’t react with chlorine
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the molecular structure of chlorine gas? Options: A. Cl, B. Cl2, C. Cl3, D. Cl4 Correct Option: B
Question 2: Why was chlorine not an effective chemical weapon during World War I? Options: A. It was not toxic enough, B. It was difficult to produce, C. It could easily blow back to the people releasing it, D. It was not dense enough Correct Option: C
Question 3: What happens when chlorine reacts with water? Options: A. It forms hydrochloric acid, B. It forms oxygen gas, C. It forms hydrogen gas, D. It forms ammonia Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the primary use of chlorine produced through electrolysis? Options: A. Making PVC, B. Making hydrochloric acid, C. Making aluminum trichloride, D. Making iron chloride Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the byproduct of the reaction between chlorine and aluminum? Options: A. Aluminum oxide, B. Aluminum trichloride, C. Hydrochloric acid, D. Oxygen gas Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the reason for the high reactivity of chlorine? Options: A. It has a full outer energy level, B. It has a noble gas configuration, C. It wants to gain an electron to achieve a noble gas configuration, D. It wants to lose an electron to achieve a noble gas configuration Correct Option: C
Question 7: If you were to design a safe storage container for chlorine gas, what material would you avoid using? Options: A. Lead, B. Aluminum, C. Iron, D. Brass Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the result of the reaction between chlorine and iron? Options: A. Iron oxide, B. Iron chloride, C. Hydrochloric acid, D. Oxygen gas Correct Option: B
Question 9: Why is it safe to consume chloride ions, but not chlorine gas? Options: A. Chloride ions are not reactive, B. Chloride ions are not toxic, C. Chloride ions have a full outer energy level, D. Chloride ions have a noble gas configuration Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the primary source of chlorine in the world? Options: A. Salt lakes, B. Prehistoric deposits, C. Sodium chloride solution, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

and if you put in other metals like aluminium or iron
they will also react. Aluminium reacts to form aluminium
trichloride which is the salt of aluminium and iron will
similarly react to form iron chloride, and most metals
but not all of them will react with chlorine: lead will
not for example. But it is really quite a reactive
gas. So really rapid reaction there as the hot
iron starts to react with the chlorine to form iron chloride.
Very, very exothermic again and I think, yes this is
very hot, we might have to move it off the paper. So what happens in all of these reactions
is that the chlorine removes an electron from the metal
to make the chloride ion Cl-, and the chloride ion
is perfectly innocuous, you can drink, you can eat chloride,
whereas chlorine itself is very poisonous. Oh it’s warm, it’s not too hot to touch
its like picking up a mug of warm tea or warm coffee. But you
can see again the products of the chemical reaction
have precipitated out across the flask, and now
if I remove the…wire again I can see that all of the
iron has been consumed again instantly. The moment that
it got into that chlorine-rich flask; very, very rapid
reaction, very, very reactive with chlorine.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Chlorine reacts with almost all metals, but according to the professor, which one does not react with chlorine?
Options: A. Iron, B. Aluminum, C. Lead
Correct Option: C

Question 2: Why was chlorine not an effective chemical weapon during World War I? Options: A. It was not toxic enough, B. It was difficult to produce, C. It could easily blow back to the people releasing it, D. It was not dense enough Correct Option: C
Question 3: What happens when chlorine reacts with water? Options: A. It forms hydrochloric acid, B. It forms oxygen gas, C. It forms hydrogen gas, D. It forms ammonia Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the primary use of chlorine produced through electrolysis? Options: A. Making PVC, B. Making hydrochloric acid, C. Making aluminum trichloride, D. Making iron chloride Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the byproduct of the reaction between chlorine and aluminum? Options: A. Aluminum oxide, B. Aluminum trichloride, C. Hydrochloric acid, D. Oxygen gas Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the reason for the high reactivity of chlorine? Options: A. It has a full outer energy level, B. It has a noble gas configuration, C. It wants to gain an electron to achieve a noble gas configuration, D. It wants to lose an electron to achieve a noble gas configuration Correct Option: C
Question 7: If you were to design a safe storage container for chlorine gas, what material would you avoid using? Options: A. Lead, B. Aluminum, C. Iron, D. Brass Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the result of the reaction between chlorine and iron? Options: A. Iron oxide, B. Iron chloride, C. Hydrochloric acid, D. Oxygen gas Correct Option: B
Question 9: Why is it safe to consume chloride ions, but not chlorine gas? Options: A. Chloride ions are not reactive, B. Chloride ions are not toxic, C. Chloride ions have a full outer energy level, D. Chloride ions have a noble gas configuration Correct Option: B

that they've done before where you take a heavy element with a heavy nucleus and bombard it with lighter elements and you choose the combination so that the mass of the light element and the heavy element makes the one you're trying to synthesize so in this case the experiments described in this paper are taking titanium which has atomic number 22 and californium which has atomic number 98 and if you add 22 plus 98 you get a hundred and twenty so the experiment consists of accelerating nuclei of titanium atoms at enormous ly high speed a fraction of the speed of light and letting it bang in to the sample of californium and most of the time the titanium just bounces off in some random direction but what they hope is that every so often and it hasn't happened yet but every so often one of these titanium nuclei will hit the californium in such a way that it will go inside and you can see it's quite a hard process but it can go inside so you then have the combined nucleus with mass 120 + this nucleus then shoots out of the back of the target and towards your detector but there's all sorts of fragments of atoms being knocked out to the back of the target so the key is that you have to have a really good separator based on magnetic fields so if you make a nucleus of 120 element 120 it will whiz out and hit the detector without most of the other junk once it gets to the detector as with previous super-heavy elements it will all being will stick into the detector and then once it's there it will begin decaying and out of the nucleus will come smaller fragments what the point of the experiment is that people can predict fairly accurately what would come out of a nucleus of element 120 if it was made so if they see those bits they can recognize they've made element 120 so far they haven't seen anything at all the experiments that were described in this paper are being done in the Institute in dumb start where we visited a few months ago to look at elements like Boreum and hassium where they were synthesized the reason why the experiments get difficult is each time the nucleus you're trying to make gets heavier the chances of your accelerated atom and the target fusing together get smaller and smaller and smaller so the experiment gets more and more difficult to do you have to understand the titanium atoms are coming a billions every second and they're running the experiments for weeks if not months in the hope of just seeing one atom coming out so the probability is pretty small the reason why they're trying to make 120 rather than 119 which would be the next The difficulty in obtaining the necessary materials, C. The low probability of successful fusion, D. The complexity of the experimental design Correct Option: C

By measuring the energy released in the reaction, C. By analyzing the decay products of the nucleus, D. By observing the color change of the sample Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[ music ] A Tetrad of Lunar Eclipses – presented by Science@NASA For people in the United States, an extraordinary series of lunar eclipses is about to begin. The action starts on April 15th when the full Moon passes through the amber shadow of Earth, producing a midnight eclipse visible across North America. That night marks the beginning of a lunar eclipse tetrad a series of 4 consecutive total eclipses occurring at six month intervals. The total eclipse of April 15, 2014, will be followed by another on Oct. 8, 2014, and another on April 4, 2015, and another on Sept. 28 2015. 'The most unique thing about the 2014-2015 tetrad is that all of them are visible for all or parts of the USA,' says longtime NASA eclipse expert Fred Espenak. On average, lunar eclipses occur about twice a year, but not all of them are total. There are three types: A penumbral eclipse is when the Moon passes through the pale outskirts of Earth's shadow. It's so subtle, sky watchers often don't notice an eclipse is underway. A partial eclipse is more dramatic. The Moon dips into the core of Earth's shadow, but not all the way, so only a fraction of Moon is darkened. A total eclipse, when the entire Moon is shadowed, is best of all. The face of the Moon turns sunset-red for up to an hour or more as the eclipse slowly unfolds. Usually, lunar eclipses come in no particular order. A partial can be followed by a total, followed by a penumbral, and so on. Anything goes. Occasionally, though, the sequence is more orderly. When four consecutive lunar eclipses are all total, the series is called a tetrad. 'During the 21st century, there are 9 sets of tetrads, so I would describe tetrads as a frequent occurrence in the current pattern of lunar eclipses,' says Espenak. 'But this has not always been the case. During the three hundred year interval from 1600 to 1900, for instance, there were no tetrads at all.' The April 15th eclipse begins at 2 AM Eastern time when the edge of the Moon first enters the amber core of Earth's shadow. Totality occurs during a 78 minute interval beginning around 3 o'clock in the morning on the east coast, midnight on the west coast. Weather permitting, the red Moon will be easy to see across the entirety of North America. Why red? A quick trip to the Moon provides the answer: Imagine yourself standing on a dusty lunar plain looking up at the sky. Overhead hangs Earth, nightside down, completely hiding the sun behind it. The eclipse is underway. You might expect Earth seen in this way to be utterly dark, but it's not. The rim of the planet seems to be on fire! As you scan your eye around Earth's circumference, you're seeing every sunrise and every sunset in the world, all of them, all at once. This incredible light beams into the heart of Earth's shadow, filling it with a coppery glow and transforming the Moon into a great red orb. Mark your calendar for April 15th, and let the tetrad begin! For more rare occurrences in the night's sky, stay tuned to science.nasa.gov

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many consecutive lunar eclipses are there in a lunar eclipse tetrad?
Options: A. 3, B. 4, C. 6
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the series of four consecutive total lunar eclipses occurring at six-month intervals? Options: A. Lunar Eclipse Quartet, B. Tetrad of Lunar Eclipses, C. Lunar Eclipse Cycle, D. Total Eclipse Series Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the primary reason for the Moon's red appearance during a total lunar eclipse? Options: A. The Earth's atmosphere reflects sunlight onto the Moon's surface, B. The Earth's shadow on the Moon causes the color change, C. The rim of the Earth seems to be on fire due to the visibility of every sunrise and sunset, filling the Earth's shadow with a coppery glow, D. The Moon's surface is composed of red rock Correct Option: C
Question 3: According to Fred Espenak, what is unique about the 2014-2015 tetrad of lunar eclipses? Options: A. They are the longest total eclipses of the century, B. They are the first tetrads to occur in the 21st century, C. All of them are visible for all or parts of the USA, D. They occur at 12-month intervals Correct Option: C
Question 4: What type of lunar eclipse occurs when the Moon passes through the pale outskirts of Earth's shadow? Options: A. Partial Eclipse, B. Total Eclipse, C. Penumbral Eclipse, D. Annular Eclipse Correct Option: C
Question 5: If you were standing on the Moon during a total lunar eclipse, what would you see when looking up at the Earth? Options: A. A completely dark Earth, B. The sun shining through the Earth's atmosphere, C. The rim of the Earth seeming to be on fire due to the visibility of every sunrise and sunset, D. The Earth's surface illuminated by the Moon's reflected light Correct Option: C
Question 6: How many sets of tetrads are there during the 21st century, according to Fred Espenak? Options: A. 5, B. 9, C. 12, D. 15 Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the approximate duration of the total eclipse on April 15th, as seen from the east coast of North America? Options: A. 30 minutes, B. 45 minutes, C. 78 minutes, D. 2 hours Correct Option: C
Question 8: Imagine you are planning a trip to observe the April 15th lunar eclipse. What factor would most likely affect your ability to see the eclipse? Options: A. Time zone, B. Weather conditions, C. Location within North America, D. Type of telescope used Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the name of the NASA expert who provided information about the 2014-2015 tetrad of lunar eclipses? Options: A. Fred Espenak, B. Mark NASA, C. John Smith, D. Jane Doe Correct Option: A
Question 10: Why did tetrads not occur at all during the 300-year interval from 1600 to 1900, according to Fred Espenak? Options: A. The Earth's rotation slowed down, B. The Moon's orbit changed, C. The pattern of lunar eclipses was different during that time, D. The reason is not specified in the transcript Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the question content and intent, the most similar generated MCQ is Question 1. 

Although Question 1 does not directly ask about the number of consecutive lunar eclipses in a tetrad, it does define what a tetrad is, which is "a series of four consecutive total lunar eclipses occurring at six-month intervals." This definition implies that a tetrad consists of four consecutive lunar eclipses.

**Transcript**:
[ music ] A Tetrad of Lunar Eclipses – presented by Science@NASA For people in the United States, an extraordinary series of lunar eclipses is about to begin. The action starts on April 15th when the full Moon passes through the amber shadow of Earth, producing a midnight eclipse visible across North America. That night marks the beginning of a lunar eclipse tetrad a series of 4 consecutive total eclipses occurring at six month intervals. The total eclipse of April 15, 2014, will be followed by another on Oct. 8, 2014, and another on April 4, 2015, and another on Sept. 28 2015. 'The most unique thing about the 2014-2015 tetrad is that all of them are visible for all or parts of the USA,' says longtime NASA eclipse expert Fred Espenak. On average, lunar eclipses occur about twice a year, but not all of them are total. There are three types: A penumbral eclipse is when the Moon passes through the pale outskirts of Earth's shadow. It's so subtle, sky watchers often don't notice an eclipse is underway. A partial eclipse is more dramatic. The Moon dips into the core of Earth's shadow, but not all the way, so only a fraction of Moon is darkened. A total eclipse, when the entire Moon is shadowed, is best of all. The face of the Moon turns sunset-red for up to an hour or more as the eclipse slowly unfolds. Usually, lunar eclipses come in no particular order. A partial can be followed by a total, followed by a penumbral, and so on. Anything goes. Occasionally, though, the sequence is more orderly. When four consecutive lunar eclipses are all total, the series is called a tetrad. 'During the 21st century, there are 9 sets of tetrads, so I would describe tetrads as a frequent occurrence in the current pattern of lunar eclipses,' says Espenak. 'But this has not always been the case. During the three hundred year interval from 1600 to 1900, for instance, there were no tetrads at all.' The April 15th eclipse begins at 2 AM Eastern time when the edge of the Moon first enters the amber core of Earth's shadow. Totality occurs during a 78 minute interval beginning around 3 o'clock in the morning on the east coast, midnight on the west coast. Weather permitting, the red Moon will be easy to see across the entirety of North America. Why red? A quick trip to the Moon provides the answer: Imagine yourself standing on a dusty lunar plain looking up at the sky. Overhead hangs Earth, nightside down, completely hiding the sun behind it. The eclipse is underway. You might expect Earth seen in this way to be utterly dark, but it's not. The rim of the planet seems to be on fire! As you scan your eye around Earth's circumference, you're seeing every sunrise and every sunset in the world, all of them, all at once. This incredible light beams into the heart of Earth's shadow, filling it with a coppery glow and transforming the Moon into a great red orb. Mark your calendar for April 15th, and let the tetrad begin! For more rare occurrences in the night's sky, stay tuned to science.nasa.gov

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: On average, lunar eclipses occur how many times a year?
Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 6
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

**Transcript**:
[ music ] A Tetrad of Lunar Eclipses – presented by Science@NASA For people in the United States, an extraordinary series of lunar eclipses is about to begin. The action starts on April 15th when the full Moon passes through the amber shadow of Earth, producing a midnight eclipse visible across North America. That night marks the beginning of a lunar eclipse tetrad a series of 4 consecutive total eclipses occurring at six month intervals. The total eclipse of April 15, 2014, will be followed by another on Oct. 8, 2014, and another on April 4, 2015, and another on Sept. 28 2015. 'The most unique thing about the 2014-2015 tetrad is that all of them are visible for all or parts of the USA,' says longtime NASA eclipse expert Fred Espenak. On average, lunar eclipses occur about twice a year, but not all of them are total. There are three types: A penumbral eclipse is when the Moon passes through the pale outskirts of Earth's shadow. It's so subtle, sky watchers often don't notice an eclipse is underway. A partial eclipse is more dramatic. The Moon dips into the core of Earth's shadow, but not all the way, so only a fraction of Moon is darkened. A total eclipse, when the entire Moon is shadowed, is best of all. The face of the Moon turns sunset-red for up to an hour or more as the eclipse slowly unfolds. Usually, lunar eclipses come in no particular order. A partial can be followed by a total, followed by a penumbral, and so on. Anything goes. Occasionally, though, the sequence is more orderly. When four consecutive lunar eclipses are all total, the series is called a tetrad. 'During the 21st century, there are 9 sets of tetrads, so I would describe tetrads as a frequent occurrence in the current pattern of lunar eclipses,' says Espenak. 'But this has not always been the case. During the three hundred year interval from 1600 to 1900, for instance, there were no tetrads at all.' The April 15th eclipse begins at 2 AM Eastern time when the edge of the Moon first enters the amber core of Earth's shadow. Totality occurs during a 78 minute interval beginning around 3 o'clock in the morning on the east coast, midnight on the west coast. Weather permitting, the red Moon will be easy to see across the entirety of North America. Why red? A quick trip to the Moon provides the answer: Imagine yourself standing on a dusty lunar plain looking up at the sky. Overhead hangs Earth, nightside down, completely hiding the sun behind it. The eclipse is underway. You might expect Earth seen in this way to be utterly dark, but it's not. The rim of the planet seems to be on fire! As you scan your eye around Earth's circumference, you're seeing every sunrise and every sunset in the world, all of them, all at once. This incredible light beams into the heart of Earth's shadow, filling it with a coppery glow and transforming the Moon into a great red orb. Mark your calendar for April 15th, and let the tetrad begin! For more rare occurrences in the night's sky, stay tuned to science.nasa.gov

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the technology that Bruce Aylward is confident nobody is thinking about?
Options: A. Desktop computers, B. Polio vaccine, C. Machine gun, D. Highspeed trains
Correct Option: B

The disease was controlled but not eradicated, C. A vaccine was developed that stopped the disease, D. The disease was ignored Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the main goal of the polio eradication program, according to the speaker? Options: A. To control the spread of polio, B. To reduce the number of cases of polio, C. To eradicate polio completely, D. To develop a new vaccine Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is one of the challenges of eradicating polio, according to the speaker? Options: A. The virus is highly contagious, B. The virus can survive for a long time in the environment, C. The vaccine is not effective in certain conditions, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the name of the group that has been working to eradicate polio for over 20 years, according to the speaker? Options: A. Rotary International, B. The World Health Organization, C. The Polio Eradication Program, D. The International Committee of the Red Cross Correct Option: A

Question 9: Why is it important to finish the job of eradicating polio, according to the speaker? Options: A. Because it is a major public health concern, B. Because it is a social justice issue, C. Because it is a great buy, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the speaker's final message to the audience? Options: A. To give up on the effort to eradicate polio, B. To continue to support the effort to eradicate polio, C. To ignore the issue of polio, D. To wait for someone else to take action Correct Option: B

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which US President launched a campaign to find the cure for polio?
Options: A. Theodore Roosevelt, B. Franklin D. Roosevelt, C. Ronald Regan, D. John F. Kennedy
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the devastating disease that the speaker mentioned was a major public health concern in the past? Options: A. Smallpox, B. Polio, C. SARS, D. Pandemic flu Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the speaker, what was the result of the National effort to find a way to stop polio in the United States? Options: A. The disease spread rapidly, B. The disease was controlled but not eradicated, C. A vaccine was developed that stopped the disease, D. The disease was ignored Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the main goal of the polio eradication program, according to the speaker? Options: A. To control the spread of polio, B. To reduce the number of cases of polio, C. To eradicate polio completely, D. To develop a new vaccine Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is one of the challenges of eradicating polio, according to the speaker? Options: A. The virus is highly contagious, B. The virus can survive for a long time in the environment, C. The vaccine is not effective in certain conditions, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the name of the group that has been working to eradicate polio for over 20 years, according to the speaker? Options: A. Rotary International, B. The World Health Organization, C. The Polio Eradication Program, D. The International Committee of the Red Cross Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the estimated cost of reaching 500 million children with the polio vaccine each year, according to the speaker? Options: A. $100 million, B. $500 million, C. $750 million to $800 million, D. $1 billion Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the result of the new vaccine that was developed to target the last two types of polio, according to the speaker? Options: A. It had the same impact as the old vaccine, B. It had half the impact of the old vaccine, C. It had twice the impact of the old vaccine, D. It had no impact Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the current situation with polio in India, according to the speaker? Options: A. The disease is spreading rapidly, B. The disease is under control but not eradicated, C. The disease has been eradicated, D. There have been no cases of polio in the last 6 months Correct Option: D
Question 9: Why is it important to finish the job of eradicating polio, according to the speaker? Options: A. Because it is a major public health concern, B. Because it is a social justice issue, C. Because it is a great buy, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the speaker's final message to the audience? Options: A. To give up on the effort to eradicate polio, B. To continue to support the effort to eradicate polio, C. To ignore the issue of polio, D. To wait for someone else to take action Correct Option: B
